questions.text: A 40-year-old women presented to the clinic with a 4 cm mass in the upper outer quadrant. Biopsy from the mass showed densely packed cells with bland nuclei and mucin infiltrating the stroma. Which of the following is your diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The presence of mucin infiltrating the stroma along with bland nuclei confirms the diagnosis of colloid carcinoma, a subtype of breast cancer with a relatively favourable prognosis Other options: B) Tubular carcinoma: Composed of well-formed tubules with angulated borders, and does not show mucin infiltration C) Papillary carcinoma: Characterized by papillary architecture with fibrovascular cores. Typically found in older women and does not feature mucin infiltration D) Medullary carcinoma: Composed of sheets of large pleomorphic cells with prominent lymphoplasmacytic infiltration and does not have mucin in the stroma

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with a long history of dyspnea, chronic cough, sputum production, and wheezing dies of respiratory failure following a bout of lobar pneumonia. She was not a smoker or alcoholic. The lung at autopsy is shown in the image. Which of the following underlying conditions was most likely associated with the pathologic changes shown here?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The autopsy findings in the lung suggest a condition associated with emphysema, specifically pan acinar emphysema, which is characteristic of alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) deficiency. This condition often occurs in younger individuals who are non-smokers and have a history of respiratory symptoms such as dyspnea, chronic cough, and sputum production. Other options: A) Mutation in dynein arms: Seen in primary ciliary dyskinesia (Kartagener syndrome), associated with bronchiectasis, chronic sinusitis, and situs inversus. This condition does not cause emphysema B) Cystic fibrosis: Typically presents with bronchiectasis and recurrent infections due to thickened mucus. It does not lead to emphysema D) Antibodies against type IV collagen: Seen in Goodpasture syndrome, which causes pulmonary hemorrhage and glomerulonephritis, not emphysema

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presented to the clinic with history of fatigue and tiredness. On investigation he was found to have Hb values of – 9gm%, MCV of 101 FL. Peripheral smear examination showed macrocytic RBC and hypersegmented neutrophils. Which of the following is the most likely etiology?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The patient's findings suggest macrocytic anemia, characterized by MCV >100 fL (macrocytic RBCs) and hypersegmented neutrophils on peripheral smear. These findings are consistent with megaloblastic anemia, commonly caused by vitamin B12 or folate deficiency. In this case, chronic alcoholism is the most likely etiology. Other options: A) Lead poisoning: Associated with microcytic anemia and basophilic stippling, not macrocytosis B) Iron deficiency anemia: Results in microcytic hypochromic anemia, not macrocytosis or hypersegmented neutrophils D) Hemolytic anemia: Causes normocytic or macrocytic anemia but lacks hypersegmented neutrophils. Hemolysis would also show increased reticulocyte count, which is not mentioned here

questions.text: Which of the following infection is common within 1-4 months post transplant?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) CMV is the most common opportunistic viral infection seen in solid organ transplant recipients (kidney, liver, heart, etc.) within the first 1-4 months post-transplant Other options: B) Herpes (HSV): Herpes simplex virus (HSV) infections typically present early in post-transplantation, but they are less common than CMV in the 1-4 months period. HSV infections often occur immediately after transplantation (days to weeks), and can cause mucocutaneous lesions or more serious complications if not treated C) Varicella (VZV): Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) infections, while a concern, are less frequent than CMV during the first 1-4 months post-transplant. VZV can lead to shingles or chickenpox, especially in those who have not been vaccinated or previously infected, but it is not as common as CMV during this early period D) EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus): EBV infection can also occur post-transplant, and it is a concern for post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorder (PTLD). However, EBV-related issues typically arise later (after 3-6 months post-transplant), especially in those who are EBV-negative recipients receiving an EBV-positive organ

questions.text: Type of collagen present in skin is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) In the skin, the predominant type of collagen is Type I collagen. Type I collagen provides tensile strength and is the most abundant collagen type in the body. It forms the major structural component of the skin's dermis Other options: B) Type 2 collagen: Type II collagen is primarily found in cartilage and is involved in providing strength and flexibility to joints C) Type 3 collagen: While Type III is present in the skin, it is not the primary collagen type in normal, healthy skin, although it is important in wound healing and skin elasticity D) Type 4 collagen: This type is part of the basement membrane and is important for supporting the epidermis and other epithelial layers, but it is not the major collagen type in the dermis

questions.text: Vitamin A is stored in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Cells of Ito (also known as stellate cells or lipid-storing cells) are specialized cells in the liver that store vitamin A in the form of retinyl esters. These cells are in the space of Disse between the liver's hepatocytes and endothelial cells Other options: B) Hepatocytes: While hepatocytes play a key role in metabolizing and converting vitamin A to its active forms, they are not the primary storage site. Vitamin A is stored in the Ito cells C) Endothelial cells: These cells line blood vessels and do not play a significant role in storing vitamin A D) Kupffer cells: These are liver macrophages that are involved in immune surveillance and do not store vitamin A

questions.text: Glanzmann thrombasthenia is due to
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Glanzmann thrombasthenia is a rare inherited bleeding disorder caused by a deficiency or functional defect in the glycoprotein IIb/IIIa (GpIIb/IIIa) complex on platelets. This complex is essential for platelet aggregation as it allows platelets to bind fibrinogen and form a stable clot. Other options: A) Decreased Gp1b: This is the cause of Bernard-Soulier syndrome, not Glanzmann thrombasthenia. Gp1b is a receptor involved in platelet adhesion, especially to von Willebrand factor C) Anti Gp2b/3a antibodies: This would be seen in immune thrombocytopenia (ITP) or some other autoimmune conditions but is not the cause of Glanzmann thrombasthenia D) Inhibition or deficiency of ADAMTS13: This is the cause of Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), not Glanzmann thrombasthenia

questions.text: Apoptotic gene among the following is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) BAX (Bcl-2-associated X protein) is a pro-apoptotic gene that plays a role in initiating apoptosis. It promotes cell death by enhancing the mitochondrial pathway of apoptosis Other options: B) BCL2: This is an anti-apoptotic gene that inhibits apoptosis by preventing mitochondrial membrane permeabilization, thus promoting cell survival C) BCLX: This gene is part of the Bcl-2 family and has both pro-apoptotic and anti-apoptotic isoforms, but its main function in the context of apoptosis regulation is like BCL2 in promoting survival D) BAK: This is a pro-apoptotic protein, but it functions differently from BAX. While both are involved in apoptosis, BAX is more commonly associated with the initiation of mitochondrial-driven apoptosis

questions.text: Alpha 1 antitrypsin works by
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) is a serine protease inhibitor (serpin) that primarily inhibits proteases, particularly neutrophil elastase. Neutrophil elastase is an enzyme released by neutrophils during inflammation, and if left unchecked, it can damage tissues such as the lungs. Other options: A) Inhibition of trypsin: While alpha-1 antitrypsin can inhibit other proteases, its primary action is not on trypsin but on elastase and similar proteases B) Inhibition of trypsinogen: Alpha-1 antitrypsin does not act directly on trypsinogen, the inactive form of trypsin D) Inhibition of chymotrypsinogen: Chymotrypsinogen is another inactive precursor enzyme, but alpha-1 antitrypsin is not primarily known for inhibiting this enzyme

questions.text: Which one of the following is an autosomal recessive disorder?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Albinism is an autosomal recessive genetic disorder, meaning that a person must inherit two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent) in order to express the condition. Albinism is characterized by a lack of melanin, the pigment responsible for color in the skin, hair, and eyes, leading to lighter skin, hair, and vision problems. Other options: B) Huntington disease: Huntington's disease is autosomal dominant, meaning only one copy of the mutated gene is required to express the disease C) Marfan syndrome: Marfan syndrome is also autosomal dominant, meaning a single mutated gene copy from one parent is enough to cause the condition, which affects connective tissue D) NF-1 (Neurofibromatosis type 1): This is autosomal dominant, where a person needs only one mutated gene copy to manifest the disease, which causes growth of tumors along nerves

questions.text: Follicular lymphoma is positive for?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) BCL 2 Follicular lymphoma is a type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that commonly expresses BCL-2, an anti-apoptotic protein Other options: A) BCL 1: This is typically associated with mantle cell lymphoma, not follicular lymphoma B) BCL 6: This is typically seen in germinal center B-cell lymphomas, but BCL-6 is not the defining marker for follicular lymphoma D) None of the above: This is incorrect, as BCL-2 is the characteristic marker for follicular lymphoma

questions.text: What is the histological difference between ulcerative colitis and crohns disease
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Pseudo polyps are characteristic of ulcerative colitis. Pseudopolyps are remnants of inflamed and regenerating mucosal tissue that form due to the healing of ulcerations. They appear as raised structures, but they are not true polyps, as they do not contain a stalk. Other options: Mucosal edema: This is seen in both ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease, but it is not as characteristic as pseudopolyps in ulcerative colitis Crypt abscess: This is more characteristic of ulcerative colitis and represents the accumulation of neutrophils within the crypts of the colon. It is often seen in ulcerative colitis and helps differentiate it from Crohn's disease Lymphoid aggregation in mucosa: This is seen in Crohn's disease, where there is often lymphoid follicle formation, but it is not a hallmark of ulcerative colitis

questions.text: What is the cause of intra corpuscular defects in haemolysis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) PNH The cause of an intra-corpuscular defect in hemolysis is PNH (Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria), where the defect in the red blood cell membrane leads to increased vulnerability to complement-mediated destruction. Other options: A) Uremic syndrome is a result of kidney failure, leading to a buildup of waste products in the blood. While it can cause anemia due to renal failure, it is not an intra-corpuscular defect. The anemia seen in uremia is typically normocytic and often due to decreased erythropoietin production B) PCH (Paroxysmal Cold Haemoglobinuria) is a type of hemolysis caused by cold-reacting antibodies, which is extravascular hemolysis rather than an intra-corpuscular defect. In PCH, hemolysis occurs due to the binding of cold antibodies to the RBCs at lower temperatures, leading to complement activation and RBC destruction D) Portal hypertension is primarily a vascular condition and typically does not cause intra-corpuscular defects in RBCs. It may lead to splenomegaly and hypersplenism, which can contribute to extravascular hemolysis (destruction of RBCs in the spleen), but it is not an intra-corpuscular defect

questions.text: Type of necrosis seen in blood vessels due to immune reaction
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Fibrinoid necrosis is the type of necrosis seen in blood vessels due to immune reactions, especially in conditions involving immune complex deposition like vasculitis. Other options: A) Coagulative necrosis: This type of necrosis is typically seen in tissues such as the heart, kidney, and liver, where the architecture of the tissue is preserved for a period despite cell death. It is not typically associated with blood vessels B) Liquefactive necrosis: This occurs when tissues are digested by enzymes, often seen in the brain or in abscesses where pus forms due to infection. It is not typically associated with blood vessels due to immune reactions D) Caseous necrosis: This type of necrosis is typically associated with tuberculosis or granulomatous infections, and involves the formation of a cheese-like material in the affected tissue. It is not typically seen in blood vessels due to immune reactions

questions.text: What is the function of IL -1
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) IL-1 is a pro-inflammatory cytokine and a key endogenous pyrogen, contributing to fever and the acute inflammatory response. Other options: A) Enhances hematopoiesis: IL-1 can indirectly affect hematopoiesis by promoting the release of other cytokines, this is not its primary function B) Stimulates mast cells: IL-1 is not primarily responsible for mast cell stimulation. This function is more characteristic of cytokines like IL-3 or stem cell factor C) Has antiviral properties: Cytokines like interferons (IFN-? and IFN-?) are responsible for antiviral properties, not IL-1

questions.text: IL – 1 is activated by
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Caspase 1 Caspase 1 is involved in the cleavage and activation of pro-IL-1? and pro-IL-18 into their active forms, IL-1? and IL-18. This process occurs as part of the inflammasome pathway, a critical component of the innate immune response. Other options: Caspase 3 is primarily involved in the execution phase of apoptosis, not in IL-1 activation Caspase 8 is associated with the initiation of apoptosis via the extrinsic pathway and is not involved in IL-1 processing Caspase 5 is part of the inflammasome complex but does not directly cleave pro-IL-1? into its active form

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for acute ITP
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Intravenous Immunoglobulin (IV Ig) is the treatment of choice for acute Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP) when treatment is indicated. It rapidly increases platelet counts by blocking the Fc receptors in the spleen, thereby reducing the destruction of platelets. IV Ig is especially preferred in cases where there is active bleeding or a very low platelet count, as it acts faster than steroids and has a good safety profile in children. A. Blood transfusion Incorrect. Blood transfusion is not the treatment of choice for ITP, since the problem lies in platelet destruction, not red blood cells. Transfusion is only considered in cases of life-threatening hemorrhage, and even then, platelet transfusions may be needed — not whole blood. B. Spontaneous recovery Incorrect. While many cases of acute ITP in children do resolve on their own, this is not considered a treatment. Observation is appropriate in mild cases, but the question asks for the treatment of choice, which refers to what should be done when intervention is necessary. D. Splenectomy Incorrect. Splenectomy is generally reserved for chronic ITP or refractory cases that do not respond to first-line treatments like IV Ig or steroids. It is not used in the acute phase, especially not in children.

questions.text: First feature of Crohn
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Crohn's Disease often begins with subtle mucosal changes, and the earliest histological feature is aphthous ulcers. These are small, shallow ulcers in the mucosa that are typically the first visible sign of the disease Other options: Deep fissures: As the inflammation worsens, deep ulcers and fissures develop Apple core appearance: This is a radiological finding seen in advanced cases with significant bowel narrowing Creeping fat: Refers to mesenteric fat wrapping around the intestine, a hallmark of chronic and advanced Crohn's disease

questions.text: Which of the following shows PAS positive macrophages abundantly in lamina propria?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Whipple disease is caused by Tropheryma whipplei and is characterized by the presence of PAS (Periodic Acid-Schiff) positive macrophages in the lamina propria of the small intestine. These macrophages contain the bacteria, which stain positively with PAS Other options: A) Abetalipoproteinemia: A genetic disorder involving defects in fat absorption, but it does not feature PAS-positive macrophages B) H. Pylori: Helicobacter pylori infection is linked to gastric ulcers and chronic gastritis but does not involve PAS-positive macrophages in the lamina propria C) Agammaglobulinemia: A condition involving a deficiency in antibodies, which does not feature PAS-positive macrophages

questions.text: Mutation seen in Cowden syndrome is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Cowden syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by multiple noncancerous, tumor-like growths (hamartomas) and an increased risk of developing various types of cancer. The mutation responsible for Cowden syndrome is in the PTEN gene, which is a tumor suppressor gene Other options: A) TP53: Mutations in the TP53 gene are associated with Li-Fraumeni syndrome, not Cowden syndrome B) RB: The RB gene is associated with retinoblastoma and other cancers, but not Cowden syndrome D) PTCH: Mutations in PTCH are associated with Gorlin syndrome, which is characterized by basal cell carcinoma and other features, not Cowden syndrome

questions.text: Deficiency of CD-59 causes?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Deficiency of CD59 is associated with PNH, a disorder where red blood cells are vulnerable to complement-mediated destruction Other options: A) Thalassemia: Thalassemia is caused by mutations in the genes encoding hemoglobin and is not related to CD59 deficiency C) G6PD Deficiency: G6PD deficiency results in oxidative stress-induced hemolysis, but it is not related to CD59 deficiency D) Sickle Cell Anemia: Sickle cell anemia is caused by a mutation in the hemoglobin gene (HBB) that leads to the sickling of red blood cells, but it is unrelated to CD59 deficiency

questions.text: Extra mammary Paget disease is seen at what site?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Vulva Extramammary Paget disease (EMPD) is a rare form of intraepithelial carcinoma that typically affects the vulva in women, though it can also affect other areas of the body, including the perineum, scrotum, and anus Other options: B) Vagina: Paget disease of the vagina is very rare. It can sometimes involve the vulva and vagina together, but vulvar involvement is much more common C) Uterus: Paget disease is not typically found in the uterus D) Cervix: While the cervix can develop other types of squamous or glandular neoplasms, extramammary Paget disease is not commonly found in this location

questions.text: What is the diagnosis in the gross picture of lung provided below-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Miliary tuberculosis (TB) is characterized by the presence of numerous small, millet seed-like granulomas scattered throughout the lungs. This form of TB results from the hematogenous spread of Mycobacterium tuberculosis, causing tiny, uniform nodules (granulomas) to form in various organs, most notably in the lungs On gross examination, the lungs in miliary TB typically show numerous small, white or yellowish nodules scattered throughout the lung parenchyma, resembling millet seeds Other options: B) Bronchiectasis: This is characterized by dilated and thickened airways. It often presents with recurrent infections and copious sputum production. Grossly, the lungs may show dilated bronchi but not the miliary nodules C) Emphysema: In emphysema, the lungs show enlarged airspaces due to destruction of the alveolar walls, which leads to a loss of lung elasticity. It does not present with miliary nodules D) COPD: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) may show changes like emphysema and chronic bronchitis but does not present with the characteristic miliary nodules seen in miliary tuberculosis

questions.text: Minimum time in which Onset of TRALI occurs in-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 6 hrs Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) is a serious and often fatal complication of blood transfusion. It typically presents with acute respiratory distress and hypoxemia following the transfusion of blood products, particularly platelets and plasma-containing products The onset of TRALI usually occurs within 6 hours of the transfusion, making it a rapidly developing condition Other options: B) 12 hours: TRALI typically occurs much sooner than 12 hours C) 48 hours: This is too long for the typical onset of TRALI D) 72 hours: This is also too long for TRALI onset

questions.text: Which of the following is true about ataxia telangiectasia- 1. It is an autosomal dominant disease 2. It predisposes to squamous cell carcinoma 3. It does not affect before the age of 5 4. Immune system is not affected
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) None of the above

questions.text: A 20-years-old woman presented with red firm two soft elevate lesion on anterior chest wall which were painless. The lesion has increased in size slowly. After excision following histopathology was seen. Diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Capillary hemangiomas are benign vascular tumors that commonly present as reddish, firm, or soft lesions on the skin or mucous membranes. They are usually painless and may increase in size slowly over time. The histopathological appearance of capillary hemangiomas typically shows clusters of small blood vessels (capillaries) surrounded by connective tissue Other options: B) Fibroadenoma: This typically occurs in the breast, presenting as a painless, mobile, firm mass. It's not usually found in the chest wall in young women, and its histopathology shows glandular and fibrous tissue C) Lipoma: A lipoma is a benign fatty tumor that typically presents as a soft, movable, and painless mass under the skin. The histology would show mature adipose tissue, unlike the capillary hemangioma D) Paget's disease: This is usually a type of cancer affecting the nipple and surrounding skin, often associated with breast cancer. It would not present as a soft elevated lesion on the chest wall without other symptoms like skin changes or discharge

questions.text: What is the transporter for iron from lumen to enterocyte?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) DMT1 DMT 1 is the transporter responsible for the uptake of iron (Fe2+) from the lumen of the intestine into the enterocytes (cells of the intestinal lining). It facilitates the transport of divalent metal ions, including iron, across the apical membrane of the enterocyte Other options: B) DMT 2: This is not the correct answer, as DMT 2 is not involved in iron transport. It primarily transports other divalent cations, but it does not play a direct role in iron uptake C) Ferroportin: Ferroportin is involved in iron export from enterocytes into the bloodstream. It transports iron across the basolateral membrane of the enterocyte, not from the lumen to the enterocyte D) Hepcidin: Hepcidin is a regulatory hormone that controls iron homeostasis by inhibiting ferroportin, thus reducing iron absorption and release into the bloodstream. However, it is not a transporter

questions.text: A man died of pulmonary embolism. Following is the gross section of liver. Diagnosis is-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Liver metastasis Pulmonary embolism often leads to right-sided heart failure, which can cause congestion in organs such as the liver. In such cases, liver metastasis could be the primary cause of the observed findings in the liver Metastatic deposits in the liver are common and can sometimes present with gross changes such as nodules, discoloration, or a mass effect. Other options: A) HCC (Hepatocellular carcinoma): While HCC can cause significant liver pathology, it typically presents with liver-specific findings (e.g., cirrhosis, tumor mass), and it may not directly relate to the gross section observed after pulmonary embolism B) Lymphoma: Lymphoma can affect the liver, but it would typically present with characteristic nodular or infiltrative patterns on histology and not necessarily linked directly to pulmonary embolism as the cause of death C) TB (Tuberculosis): TB can affect the liver, but gross liver changes would typically show granulomas or caseating necrosis, which might not be the most likely finding in this case given the patient's history of pulmonary embolism

questions.text: Anaplasia of cells mean?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Anaplasia refers to the lack of differentiation of cells. It is a hallmark of malignancy and indicates that the cells have lost the features that make them resemble the normal tissue from which they originated Other options: A) Change in cells and shape: This describes cellular pleomorphism, which can be part of anaplastic cells, but it does not fully define anaplasia B) Loss of polarity: This is another feature of anaplasia, but it refers specifically to the loss of the organized structure of the cells, which is often seen in poorly differentiated tumors. It is not the entire definition of anaplasia D) Darkening of nuclear chromatin: This refers to hyperchromasia, which is a sign of increased DNA content or nuclear changes, but it is not the defining characteristic of anaplasia

questions.text: A 30 years-old male patient presents with anterior neck swelling. Microscopic image is given as following. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Hashimoto's thyroiditis is an autoimmune disorder that is characterized by the destruction of thyroid cells by antibodies, leading to hypothyroidism. The microscopic image typically shows lymphocytic infiltration and the presence of Hurthle cells (also called oncocytic cells), which are eosinophilic and contain an abundant number of mitochondria. The fibrosis of the thyroid tissue can also be seen in later stages. This is the most likely diagnosis given the clinical and histological presentation Other options: B) Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid: This cancer originates from parafollicular cells (C cells) and produces calcitonin. The microscopic findings would include amyloid deposits and neuroendocrine features, which would not match the description of Hashimoto's thyroiditis C) Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid: This type of thyroid cancer typically shows papillary architecture and nuclear features, including intranuclear inclusions and ground-glass nuclei (Orphan Annie eyes). The biopsy for Hashimoto's thyroiditis would not show these characteristics D) Graves’ disease: Graves’ disease is characterized by hyperthyroidism and diffuse hyperplasia of the thyroid with lymphocytic infiltration, but it lacks the Hurthle cells and significant fibrosis seen in Hashimoto’s thyroiditis

questions.text: Which of the following is a gastric tumor of epithelial origin?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Signet ring cell carcinoma is a form of adenocarcinoma that contains cells with a distinctive signet ring shape due to the presence of a large mucin vacuole. This is an epithelial tumor that can arise in the stomach, often as gastric cancer Other options: A) GIST (Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor): GIST is a mesenchymal tumor that originates from interstitial cells of Cajal, and is not an epithelial tumor. It is more related to smooth muscle cells and is classified as a sarcoma B) Carcinoid: Carcinoid tumors arise from neuroendocrine cells and are classified as neuroendocrine tumors rather than epithelial tumors. While they can occur in the stomach, they are not of epithelial origin C) Sarcoma: Sarcomas are mesenchymal tumors (from connective tissue, muscle, or bone), not epithelial in origin

questions.text: L&H cells are seen in which variant of Hodgkin lymphoma?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Lymphocyte predominant: L&H cells, also known as popcorn cells, are characteristic of the lymphocyte predominant variant of Hodgkin's lymphoma. These cells have a unique appearance with irregular, multilobed nuclei that resemble popcorn kernels Other options: A) Nodular sclerosis: This is the most common subtype of Hodgkin's lymphoma, characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells but not L&H (L and H) cells. It often shows bands of sclerosis between the nodules B) Mixed cellularity: This subtype of Hodgkin's lymphoma also features Reed-Sternberg cells, and is characterized by a mix of inflammatory cells, but it does not specifically feature L&H cells D) Lymphocyte depleted: This variant of Hodgkin's lymphoma is associated with a poor prognosis and features Reed-Sternberg cells. L&H cells are not seen in this subtype.

questions.text: Fever is caused due to which of the following?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) PGE2 PGE2 (Prostaglandin E2) plays a critical role in the body's response to infection or injury, including the induction of fever. It acts on the hypothalamus to increase the set point for body temperature, leading to the development of fever Other options: A) PGD2 (Prostaglandin D2): It is involved in various immune responses and plays a role in allergic reactions but does not directly cause fever B) PGF2? (Prostaglandin F2 alpha): This prostaglandin is involved in the regulation of smooth muscle tone and is mainly known for its role in uterine contraction, but it does not have a significant role in fever production D) PGE1 (Prostaglandin E1): PGE1 is involved in vasodilation and inhibition of platelet aggregation, but it is not the primary prostaglandin responsible for causing fever

questions.text: Which of the complement is known as Opsonin?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) C3b C3b is an opsonin, it promotes phagocytosis by binding to pathogens and marking them for ingestion by phagocytic cells such as macrophages and neutrophils. It plays a crucial role in the immune response. Other options: A) C3a: C3a is an anaphylatoxin and is involved in inflammation by increasing vascular permeability and stimulating mast cells to release histamine. It does not act as an opsonin C) C5a: C5a is another anaphylatoxin like C3a and is involved in the inflammatory response by attracting immune cells to the site of infection (chemotaxis) but does not function as an opsonin D) C9: C9 is part of the terminal complement complex (membrane attack complex), which helps in lysing pathogens by forming pores in their membranes but does not function as an opsonin

questions.text: Most common type of skin lymphoma is-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Mycosis fungoides: This is the most common type of primary cutaneous lymphoma. It is a cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (CTCL) that primarily involves the skin and can progress to involve lymph nodes and internal organs in advanced stages. It presents with patches, plaques, and potentially tumors on the skin Other options: B-Cell lymphoma: Primary cutaneous B-cell lymphomas are less common than T-cell lymphomas. Examples include primary cutaneous follicle center lymphoma and primary cutaneous marginal zone lymphoma Leukemia: While leukemia can involve the skin secondarily (leukemia cutis), it is not classified as a primary skin lymphoma Anaplastic: Cutaneous anaplastic large cell lymphoma (C-ALCL) is a type of T-cell lymphoma but is much less common than mycosis fungoides

questions.text: Stellate shaped granuloma with central necrosis and neutorphils is seen in-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Cat scratch disease: This condition, caused by Bartonella henselae, is characterized histologically by stellate-shaped granulomas with central necrosis and neutrophilic infiltration. It often presents as lymphadenopathy following a scratch or bite from a cat Other options: Sarcoidosis: This typically shows non-caseating granulomas without central necrosis or neutrophils TB (Tuberculosis): Histologically, it is marked by caseating granulomas, characterized by central necrosis but without a stellate shape Lymphoma: These are malignant proliferations of lymphoid cells and do not form granulomas

questions.text: Which of the following causes increase in bleeding time:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Von Willebrand disease Von Willebrand disease (vWD): This is a bleeding disorder caused by a deficiency or dysfunction of von Willebrand factor (vWF), which is essential for platelet adhesion. It results in prolonged bleeding time because of impaired platelet plug formation. Other options: Haemophilia A and C: These are coagulation factor deficiencies (Factor VIII and Factor XI, respectively) that primarily affect the clotting cascade. They result in prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) but do not significantly affect bleeding time HSP (Henoch-Schoenlein Purpura): This is a vasculitis disorder involving small vessels and does not typically cause prolonged bleeding time. It presents with purpura, abdominal pain, and joint symptoms

questions.text: Bernard-Soulier disease is caused due to defect in-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Gp Ib/IX Bernard-Soulier disease is a rare inherited bleeding disorder caused by a defect in the Gp Ib-IX complex, which is the receptor for von Willebrand factor (vWF). This receptor is crucial for platelet adhesion to the subendothelial collagen during the initial stages of clot formation. Other options: Gp IIb/IIIa: This is the receptor responsible for platelet aggregation by binding fibrinogen, which is affected in Glanzmann thrombasthenia, not Bernard-Soulier disease Factor VIII: A deficiency in this coagulation factor causes Hemophilia A, which is unrelated to platelet receptor defects Gp IIIb/IIa: This is not a recognized platelet receptor combination, so it is not relevant

questions.text: Van Nuys system of DCIS includes all except-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) ER/PR status The Van Nuys Prognostic Index (VNPI) is a scoring system used to predict the recurrence risk of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) after surgical treatment. It is based on three primary factors 1. Size of the lesion 2. Presence or absence of necrosis (especially comedonecrosis) 3. Age of the patient ER/PR status is not a component of the original Van Nuys system. While hormonal receptor status (ER/PR) is important in invasive breast cancer and influences therapy, it is not included in this specific index for DCIS

questions.text: Which cells are responsible for rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) T cells Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is primarily an autoimmune disease, and T cells play a central role in the pathogenesis of RA. T cells are involved in the initiation of inflammation by recognizing self-antigens presented by antigen-presenting cells (APCs). These T cells activate other immune cells, including B cells, macrophages, and fibroblasts, contributing to the inflammatory response and tissue damage seen in RA. Other options: B cells are also involved by producing antibodies (e.g., rheumatoid factor), it is T cells that are crucial in the early stages of the disease, triggering the autoimmune response and activating the subsequent inflammatory cascade NK cells (Natural Killer cells) are generally not the main players in RA, although they can contribute to immune regulation Macrophages are also involved in RA as they release inflammatory cytokines (e.g., TNF-?) that perpetuate the disease, but they are not the primary cells responsible for initiating the disease

questions.text: Dactylitis is seen in which condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Sickle cell anemia Dactylitis, also known as "sausage digit," is the inflammation of the fingers or toes, resulting in a swollen appearance. It is most commonly associated with Sickle cell anemia: Dactylitis is a frequent early symptom of sickle cell disease in young children, occurring due to the blockage of blood flow in small bones caused by sickled red blood cells. Other options: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and gouty arthritis can cause joint inflammation, but dactylitis is not a typical feature of these conditions. RA typically presents with joint deformities over time, and gout often presents with acute pain in specific joints like the big toe Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) can cause various types of joint involvement, but dactylitis is not a hallmark of the disease

questions.text: Tensile strength of wound after laparoscopic cholecystectomy in a 30 years old woman depends upon-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Extensive crosslinking of tropocollagen Extensive crosslinking of tropocollagen (B) refers to the final stage of collagen maturation, where collagen fibers are cross-linked and become stronger. This crosslinking provides increased tensile strength to the wound. Other options: Type 3 collagen replacement (A) is an early step in wound healing, typically replaced by Type 1 collagen over time, which contributes to strength. However, the final tensile strength is more dependent on the crosslinking of collagen fibers Macrophage activity (C) is important for inflammation and the cleanup of debris in the initial phases of healing but does not directly contribute to tensile strength Granulation tissue (D) is the tissue that forms during the healing process, providing a scaffold for collagen deposition, but it is the maturation of collagen fibers (through crosslinking) that provides the actual tensile strength to the wound

choices.text: Every 10th patient has a Y-linked disorder
1/3rd of Mendelian disorders are Autosomal recessive
Every 5th patient has an X-linked disorder
2/3rds of Mendelian disorders are autosomal dominant

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Mendelian mode of inheritance?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 2/3rd of Mendelian disorders are autosomal disorders: A significant majority of Mendelian disorders are autosomal (either dominant or recessive), with autosomal dominant disorders being more common than autosomal recessive disorders Other options: Every 10th patient has a Y-linked disorder: Y-linked disorders are extremely rare because the Y chromosome contains few genes that cause disease, and only males are affected. These are not commonly seen in clinical practice 1/3rd of Mendelian disorders is autosomal recessive: While autosomal recessive disorders are common, they don't account for as large a proportion as 1/3rd. The proportion is lower, as autosomal dominant disorders are more common Every 5th patient has an X-linked disorder: X-linked disorders are less common than autosomal disorders, and they are typically seen more often in males because they have only one X chromosome

questions.text: An elderly male, known smoker presented with chronic cough, significant weight loss and fatigue. Serum calcium level is raised. A lung biopsy showed large atypical cells with hyperchromasia. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Squamous cell carcinoma Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung is commonly associated with smoking and often presents with symptoms like chronic cough, weight loss, and fatigue. It can also cause hypercalcemia due to paraneoplastic syndromes, particularly the release of parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrP), which raises serum calcium levels. The presence of large atypical cells with hyperchromasia on lung biopsy fits with squamous cell carcinoma Other options: Small cell carcinoma (B) typically presents with more rapid progression, often associated with symptoms like cough, hemoptysis, and paraneoplastic syndromes such as SIADH (not hypercalcemia). The cells are usually smaller and have less hyperchromasia compared to what is described in this case Adenocarcinoma (C) is also linked to smoking but is generally more common in non-smokers as well. It can present with similar symptoms but typically shows glandular differentiation on histology Large cell neuroendocrine tumor (D) is a rare form of neuroendocrine tumor of the lung, which can also present with similar symptoms, but the histology often shows large, polygonal cells and neuroendocrine features, which does not match the description of large atypical cells with hyperchromasia seen here

questions.text: A young patient presents with large retroperitoneal hemorrhage. He also gives a frequent history of intermittent swelling of knees on strenuous exercise. There is no history of any mucosal bleed. Which among the following clotting factors is responsible for the above mentioned condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Factors 8 and 9 Hemophilia A (Factor 8 deficiency) and Hemophilia B (Factor 9 deficiency) are X-linked recessive disorders that typically present with spontaneous or excessive bleeding, especially into joints (hemarthrosis) after trauma or exercise. The intermittent swelling of the knees could be indicative of repeated joint bleeds (hemarthrosis), a classic feature of hemophilia. Other options: A) Lupus anticoagulant is associated with antiphospholipid syndrome and causes thrombosis, not bleeding. It does not match the described symptoms B) Factor 11 and 12: These are involved in the intrinsic pathway of coagulation, and while Factor 11 deficiency (hemophilia C) may cause bleeding, it is typically less severe than Factor 8 or 9 deficiency. Factor 12 deficiency does not usually lead to bleeding but is associated with thrombophilia D) von Willebrand disease is a common bleeding disorder, but it typically causes mucosal bleeding (nosebleeds, heavy periods, etc.) and not the deep joint or retroperitoneal hemorrhage seen in hemophilia

questions.text: Lab investigations of an elderly male shows marked elevation of lymphocytes with marked leucocytosis. The peripheral smear is given below. What is the appropriate next step for the patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The patient's presentation of marked lymphocytosis with marked leukocytosis, combined with the peripheral smear showing likely abnormal lymphocytes, raises the suspicion for a hematologic malignancy such as chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) or other types of lymphoproliferative disorders Flow cytometry is a key diagnostic tool to identify abnormal populations of cells in blood or bone marrow. It allows for the characterization of the type of lymphocytes involved, including distinguishing between different types of leukemia or lymphoma based on surface markers Other options: A) Stem cell transplantation: This is typically considered later in treatment for certain hematologic malignancies, such as leukemia or lymphoma, particularly in cases of relapse or when the disease is resistant to chemotherapy. It is not the first step B) Bone marrow biopsy: While this can be useful in the diagnosis of leukemia, lymphoma, or other hematologic disorders, it is not the initial diagnostic tool. Flow cytometry is often performed first to assess the nature of the lymphocyte population D) Start high-dose chemotherapy: This would not be the first step without a definitive diagnosis. The initial step is to determine the exact nature of the disorder using flow cytometry to guide treatment options

questions.text: A 23 year old male presented with low Hb, platelet count of 25,000/ml, gum bleeding, and raised PT and Aptt. The image of his peripheral smear is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) AML with t(15;17) The findings of low hemoglobin, low platelets, gum bleeding, and raised PT and APTT, in combination with Auer rods and faggot cells on peripheral smear, strongly suggest acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), which is characterized by the t(15;17) translocation, a unique translocation that results in the fusion of the PML gene on chromosome 15 and the RAR? gene on chromosome 17 Other options: A) AML with t (8,21): This translocation is associated with another subtype of AML, but it is not typically associated with the presence of Auer rods or faggot cells C) AML with inv 16: This translocation is associated with another subtype of AML, often with monocytic differentiation, but faggot cells are not characteristic in this subtype D) AML with t (11, 21): This translocation is less common and is not typically associated with Auer rods or faggot cells

questions.text: A chronic smoker who worked in the cement factory for the past 20 years developed mesothelioma. The association is likely due to –
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Mesothelioma is a rare and aggressive cancer that affects the mesothelial cells lining the pleura, peritoneum, or pericardium. It is most associated with exposure to asbestos. Asbestos exposure is strongly linked to the development of mesothelioma, especially in individuals who work in environments where they are exposed to asbestos fibres, such as cement factories, and shipyards. Chronic smoking increases the risk of lung cancer, but smoking alone does not directly cause mesothelioma. However, the combined risk of smoking and asbestos exposure may increase the risk of other respiratory diseases and cancers Other options: A) Silicosis: This is caused by inhalation of silica dust, commonly seen in miners, quarry workers, and stonecutters. Silicosis is associated with an increased risk of tuberculosis and certain types of lung cancer, but it is not directly linked to mesothelioma C) Coal worker pneumoconiosis: This is caused by inhalation of coal dust, seen in coal miners. It primarily causes chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and pneumoconiosis, but it is not associated with mesothelioma D) Bagassosis: This is caused by inhalation of dust from sugarcane. It leads to hypersensitivity pneumonitis, but it is not linked to mesothelioma

questions.text: A child presents with intermittent jaundice and splenomegaly. There is a history of similar complaints in the elder brother. Peripheral blood smear shows the following finding. How will you investigate this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Osmotic fragility test- Hereditary spherocytosis The most appropriate investigation for a child with intermittent jaundice, splenomegaly, and spherocytes on peripheral blood smear is the osmotic fragility test, which would support a diagnosis of hereditary spherocytosis Other options: B) Coombs test - AIHA: The Coombs test is used to diagnose autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA). While AIHA can also cause jaundice and splenomegaly, it typically presents with normocytic or macrocytic cells, not spherocytes. The peripheral smear in AIHA often shows polychromasia, reticulocytosis, and spherocytes, but the clinical presentation with a family history is more suggestive of hereditary spherocytosis C) G6PD deficiency - genetic testing: G6PD deficiency leads to hemolysis under oxidative stress (e.g., after taking certain drugs, infections, or eating fava beans), but it does not typically present with spherocytes. G6PD deficiency usually causes bite cells and blister cells on the peripheral blood smear, not spherocytes D) PNH - Flow cytometry: Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is a disorder of red blood cells characterized by hemolysis and thrombosis, but it typically presents with hemoglobinuria (dark urine, especially after waking up) and does not feature spherocytes on the peripheral blood smear. Flow cytometry is used to detect deficiencies of GPI-anchored proteins in PNH, but this is not the case here

questions.text: An African child is found to have a mass in the jaw. A biopsy of the mass is done and it appears as shown in the image below. The child also has a translocation of t(8;14). What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Burkitt lymphoma The clinical scenario and histopathology image showing “Starry sky” appearance gives a probable diagnosis of Burkitt lymphoma. Burkitt lymphoma is a B-cell Non-Hodgkin lymphoma, characterised by the translocation of the c-myc gene on chromosome 8. The translocation most commonly seen is t(8;14).

questions.text: A child presented with cola-coloured urine, hypertension, and puffiness of eyes. Lab investigations were done and creatinine was 2.5mg/dl. Treatment was started and despite treatment, the patient did not improve for the next 3 weeks. The creatinine value increased to 4.5mg/dl. Which among the following electron microscopic findings will be seen in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Subepithelial deposits The presentation of cola-coloured urine, hypertension, puffiness of the eyes, and elevated creatinine points towards a diagnosis of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). This condition typically follows an infection with group A Streptococcus and is more common in children. PSGN is characterized by immune complex deposition in the glomeruli, which leads to inflammation and damage to the glomerular filtration barrier. On electron microscopy, subepithelial deposits are seen in PSGN. Other options: A) Subendothelial deposits: These are typically seen in conditions like Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) or membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis but are not characteristic of PSGN C) Crescent formation: Crescentic glomerulonephritis (also known as rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, RPGN) can be seen in various forms of glomerulonephritis, including Goodpasture syndrome or ANCA-associated vasculitis, but crescent formation is not typical of PSGN D) Mesangial deposits: Mesangial deposits can be seen in conditions such as IgA nephropathy or membranous nephropathy, but they are not characteristic of PSGN, which is more classically associated with subepithelial deposits

questions.text: A patient was transfused 4 units of blood 2 hours ago, and now she complains of chest discomfort. X-ray shows bilateral fissural thickening. Which of the following is the most probable cause?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Fluid overload Chest discomfort after a blood transfusion, along with bilateral fissural thickening on X-ray, is highly suggestive of transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO). This condition occurs when the volume of transfused blood exceeds the circulatory capacity of the patient, leading to pulmonary edema and bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray. TACO is more likely when multiple units of blood are transfused within a short period, as in this case (4 units of blood in 2 hours). Other options: A) ABO Incompatibility: This can cause an acute hemolytic transfusion reaction, leading to symptoms such as fever, chills, back pain, hemoglobinemia, and hemoglobinuria, but chest discomfort and bilateral fissural thickening on X-ray are not typical of ABO incompatibility B) GVHD (Graft-versus-host disease): GVHD occurs when the donor's T lymphocytes attack the recipient's tissues. It can manifest with fever, rash, liver dysfunction, and diarrhea, but pulmonary findings like bilateral fissural thickening are uncommon early in GVHD. It typically presents later, often after a few days C) Hypocalcemia: Hypocalcemia due to citrate toxicity (from blood transfusions) can cause symptoms such as muscle cramps, tetany, and arrhythmias, but chest discomfort and bilateral fissural thickening on X-ray are not typical features of hypocalcemia

questions.text: A 45 year old man presents with complaints of facial puffiness, frothy urine, and hypertension. He gives a history of infection with hepatitis B. Urine examination reveals microscopic hematuria. The histopathological image of the kidney biopsy shows a spike and dome pattern. What is the diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Membranous nephropathy Spike and dome pattern on histopathological examination is characteristic of membranous nephropathy, particularly associated with immune complex deposition along the glomerular basement membrane (GBM). This pattern is caused by subepithelial deposits of immune complexes that cause thickening of the GBM with spikes of membrane material. Other options: A) Minimal change disease: Typically presents in children with nephrotic syndrome and does not show a spike and dome pattern. It's associated with effacement of foot processes on electron microscopy, not immune complex deposition C) FSGS (Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis): This is another cause of nephrotic syndrome but is not associated with spike and dome pattern. FSGS typically shows sclerosis in some but not all glomeruli and would not have the characteristic spike and dome appearance on histology D) PSGN (Post-Streptococcal Glomerulonephritis): This disease is usually associated with diffuse glomerular inflammation and immune complex deposition, but it does not present with a spike and dome pattern. PSGN would show neutrophil infiltration and crescent formation, rather than a spike and dome pattern

questions.text: A 5 year old child is brought with fever, fatigue and left ventricular dysfunction. An endomyocardial biopsy is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Lymphocytic myocarditis is an inflammation of the heart muscle (myocardium) characterized by the infiltration of lymphocytes. This type of myocarditis is often seen in viral infections, but it can also occur as an immune response or in various other conditions. The presence of lymphocytic infiltration on the biopsy supports this diagnosis Other options: A) Acute rheumatic fever: This is a complication of Group A Streptococcus throat infection, and it can cause rheumatic heart disease. While it can involve myocarditis, it is typically associated with Aschoff bodies (focal granulomas) on histology, not lymphocytic infiltration B) Chagas disease: Caused by Trypanosoma cruzi, Chagas disease can lead to myocarditis and heart failure. However, the typical histological finding is infiltration of the myocardium with amastigotes (parasites), not just lymphocytic infiltration C) Pyogenic myocarditis: This is caused by bacterial infections, and on biopsy, you would expect to see neutrophilic infiltration and the presence of bacteria, rather than just lymphocytes

questions.text: A patient presents with bone pain, renal failure, peripheral blood smear is as shown in the image. What is a likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell neoplasm characterized by lytic bone lesions causing bone pain, renal failure from light chain deposition, and hypercalcemia. Peripheral blood smear shows Mott cells Other options: A) LCH (Langerhans cell histiocytosis): This typically affects bones, but the hallmark cells are Langerhans cells (not plasma cells), and renal failure is not a common feature C) ALL (Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia): Presents with anemia, thrombocytopenia, and leukocytosis with lymphoblasts in the smear. Mott cells are not seen in ALL D) CLL (Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia): Characterized by small mature lymphocytes and smudge cells in the peripheral smear. It does not present with mott cells, bone pain, or renal failure

questions.text: A 34 year lady presents with low Hb and gum bleeding, PT, APTT are elevated, platelet counts 25000. BMA is as follows what is the translocation seen in this case?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: A child presents with fever easy fatigue, purpura and hepatosplenomegaly, TLC 40000, BMA is as follows what is likely treatment?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) This clinical scenario describes a child presenting with features suggestive of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) with features of fever, easy fatigue and purpura, hepatosplenomegaly, leucocytosis. Bone marrow aspirate shows increased lymphoblasts in ALL Treatment: The standard induction therapy for ALL in children includes vincristine, a microtubule inhibitor, and prednisolone, a glucocorticoid. These drugs help reduce the tumor burden and induce remission. Additional agents such as L-asparaginase and anthracyclines (e.g., daunorubicin) may also be included depending on the risk stratification Other options: A) Cytarabine, daunorubicin: Used in the treatment of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) C) Rituximab, vincristine: Rituximab is used for B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma or CD20-positive malignancies, not ALL D) Lenalidomide, bortezomib: These are used for multiple myeloma, not ALL

questions.text: BMA aspirate of a child is as follows, which of the following karyotype best fits into this child?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The presence of megalaryoblasts in the bone marrow aspirate is suggestive of acute megakaryoblastic leukemia (AMKL). The karyotype 47XY +21 best fits the diagnosis of acute megakaryoblastic leukemia (AMKL) in a child, particularly in the context of Down syndrome Other options: A) 45XO: Seen in Turner syndrome, which does not have a known association with AMKL C) 47XXY: Indicates Klinefelter syndrome, which is not linked to AMKL D) 47XY +13: Indicates trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome), which is associated with severe developmental anomalies and increased risk of certain cancers but not typically AMKL

questions.text: A patient presents with easy fatigue, hyperpigmented knuckles after a gastrectomy, which of the following deficiencies is likely to be the cause?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The most likely deficiency causing fatigue and hyperpigmented knuckles after gastrectomy is vitamin B12 Other options: A) Vitamin C: Deficiency typically causes scurvy, with symptoms like bleeding gums, easy bruising, and poor wound healing, but not specifically hyperpigmented knuckles C) Folic acid: While folate deficiency causes megaloblastic anemia, it does not typically result in hyperpigmentation of the knuckles. Folic acid deficiency is more commonly seen in cases of poor dietary intake or malabsorption but does not cause the skin changes seen with B12 deficiency D) Iron: Iron deficiency leads to microcytic anemia, with symptoms like fatigue and paleness, but not hyperpigmented knuckles

questions.text: A patient presents with Wheeze, respiratory distress after taking aspirin, which of the following is not true about the disease?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease is not mediated by type 1 hypersensitivity but rather by the inhibition of COX and the subsequent increased leukotriene production The condition described in the patient, who develops wheezing and respiratory distress after taking aspirin, is most likely Aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD), also known as Aspirin-induced asthma or Samter's triad. It is characterized by Asthma, nasal polyps and Aspirin intolerance or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) sensitivity Other options: B) Montelukast can help: Montelukast, a leukotriene receptor antagonist, is often used in treating AERD as it helps block the effects of leukotrienes, which are increased when COX-1 is inhibited by aspirin C) COX inhibition: AERD is primarily triggered by the inhibition of COX-1 by aspirin, leading to increased leukotriene production (since COX-1 is involved in the production of prostaglandins, and without it, the arachidonic acid pathway shunts towards leukotriene production) D) Leukotrienes induced: Increased production of leukotrienes is a key feature of AERD, and these molecules contribute to the bronchoconstriction and inflammation seen in the disease

questions.text: A patient presents with cerebellar and renal mass which of the following is most likely diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The combination of cerebellar and renal masses is highly suggestive of Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) syndrome Other options: B) Tuberous sclerosis characterized by benign tumors in the brain (such as cortical tubers), kidneys (angiomyolipoma’s), heart (rhabdomyomas), skin (ash-leaf spots, shagreen patches), and other organs. However, it is not typically associated with cerebellar masses and renal cell carcinoma, which are more characteristic of VHL C) WAGR syndrome is a rare genetic condition characterized by Wilms tumor, Aniridia, Genitourinary malformations, and Retardation. It does not typically present with cerebellar masses D) Gorlin syndrome is associated with basal cell carcinomas, odontogenic keratocysts, and medulloblastomas, but not with the combination of cerebellar and renal masses

questions.text: Histology of a renal tumor is as follows, likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The presence of a perinuclear halo in histology is characteristic of Chromophobe RCC Other options: A) Clear cell RCC: This type of RCC is characterized by cells with clear cytoplasm due to high lipid content, but it does not typically show a perinuclear halo. Instead, it may present with cellular vacuolization and well-defined boundaries C) Papillary RCC is characterized by papillary structures lined by tumor cells with foamy or eosinophilic cytoplasm, and it usually does not show the perinuclear halo seen in chromophobe RCC D) Wilms tumor is a pediatric tumor that typically exhibits small round blue cells with no distinctive perinuclear halo. It shows features like blastemal, epithelial, and stromal elements in a mixed pattern

questions.text: Likely diagnosis in the following PAP smear is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) infection is known to cause multinucleation of the epithelial cells, which is seen on the Pap smear. The cells may show intranuclear inclusions, which are also characteristic of viral infections, specifically HSV. Characteristic features include ballooning of cells, multinucleation, and the presence of intranuclear inclusions. These inclusions are often described as "Cowdry type A inclusions", which are typical in herpesvirus infections Other options: A) Trichomonas: This infection is associated with the presence of trichomonads (single-celled organisms) on the Pap smear, but not multinucleation or intranuclear inclusions. It may show pear-shaped organisms with a flagellum C) Bacterial vaginosis is caused by an imbalance of vaginal flora, leading to an increase in gram-variable rods and clue cells (vaginal epithelial cells covered with bacteria). It doesn't show multinucleation or intranuclear inclusions D) Candida can lead to yeast cells or pseudohyphae on a Pap smear but does not typically cause multinucleation or intranuclear inclusions

questions.text: Function of IL8 in ARDS is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) IL-8 is a chemokine that plays a critical role in the pathogenesis of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) by promoting neutrophil chemotaxis. This means that IL-8 attracts neutrophils to the site of infection or injury, where they release enzymes and pro-inflammatory mediators, which can exacerbate tissue damage and inflammation Other options: B) Endothelial injury: While IL-8 contributes to inflammation, it does not directly cause endothelial injury. However, neutrophil infiltration (induced by IL-8) can lead to endothelial damage C) Lymphocyte chemotaxis: IL-8 primarily targets neutrophils rather than lymphocytes. Lymphocyte chemotaxis is more typically associated with other chemokines such as IL-2 or RANTES D) Edema: IL-8 contributes to inflammation and neutrophil accumulation, which can exacerbate edema indirectly, but it is not a direct mediator of edema. Edema in ARDS is primarily due to increased vascular permeability

questions.text: Patient presents with thyroid mass, histology is as shown which of the following is most common mutation seen?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Histology image shows papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. The presence of a BRAF mutation, particularly the BRAF V600E mutation, is highly characteristic of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid Other options: B) RET: RET proto-oncogene rearrangements (RET/PTC) are also associated with papillary thyroid carcinoma, but they are more commonly found in cases linked to radiation exposure. However, BRAF mutations are more prevalent in the general population of PTC cases C) RAS: RAS mutations are more commonly associated with follicular thyroid carcinoma and poorly differentiated or anaplastic thyroid carcinoma D) Tyrosine kinase: While tyrosine kinase activation plays a role in thyroid cancers, it is not specific to papillary thyroid carcinoma and is not the most characteristic feature for this histology

questions.text: A patient presents with tingling and numbness in legs, polyurea, weight loss. Blood smear is as follows, likely diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The symptoms described, including tingling and numbness in the legs, polyuria, weight loss, and the presence of multiple plasma cells in the blood smear, are indicative of multiple myeloma. Other options: A) SACD due to vitamin B12 deficiency: Subacute combined degeneration (SACD) caused by vitamin B12 deficiency may present with neurological symptoms (tingling, numbness, ataxia). However, this condition is not associated with plasma cells in the blood smear B) SACD due to diabetes: Diabetes causes peripheral neuropathy, but it does not explain the presence of plasma cells or polyuria due to renal failure in this context D) Hereditary spherocytosis: This condition presents with anemia, jaundice, splenomegaly, and spherocytes on a peripheral smear. It does not cause tingling, numbness, or the presence of plasma cells

choices.text: Type 1 vWD is associated with a partial quantitative deficiency of Vwf
Type 2 vWD is due to qualitative defects in vWF
Type 3 vWD is associated with normal levels of vWF but defective function
Desmopressin (DDAVP) can be used in Type 1 vWD for bleeding prophylaxis

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with a history of easy bruising, prolonged bleeding after dental procedures, and heavy menstrual bleeding. Laboratory investigations reveal prolonged bleeding time, normal platelet count, and a mild prolongation of aPTT. Regarding von Willebrand disease (vWD), all of the following are true except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Statement C is false because Type 3 vWD is associated with a severe deficiency or absence of vWF, not normal levels Von Willebrand disease: Type 1 vWD: Partial quantitative deficiency of vWF; accounts for ~75% of cases Type 2 vWD: Qualitative defect; subtypes (2A, 2B, 2M, 2N) differ based on functional abnormalities Type 3 vWD: Complete absence or severe deficiency of vWF; the most severe form, with significant bleeding issues Desmopressin (DDAVP): Increases vWF release from endothelial cells; effective in mild cases like Type 1 vWD

questions.text: In a patient with Hirschprung disease which of the following layers there will be absence of ganglion cells
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The histology image shows 1. mucosa 2. submucosa 3. muscularis propria 4. serosa Hirschsprung disease is characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the myenteric (Auerbach's) plexus and submucosal (Meissner's) plexus. These ganglion cells are responsible for regulating motility In Hirschsprung disease, the ganglion cells are absent in the submucosa and muscularis propria (i.e., layers 2 and 3), leading to a failure of peristalsis and causing constipation Layer 1 (mucosa) and layer 4 (serosa) are unaffected by ganglion cell absence in Hirschsprung disease

questions.text: A child has multiple hyperpigmented skin lesions, he has a DNA repair defect which one is most likely?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Nucleotide Excision Repair (NER) is a DNA repair mechanism that removes bulky DNA lesions, such as those caused by UV light. A defect in this repair pathway leads to Xeroderma pigmentosum, which presents with hyperpigmented lesions and a higher risk of skin cancer Other options: Base excision repair (BER) repairs small base lesions caused by oxidative stress, chemicals, or spontaneous deamination. Defects in this pathway can lead to conditions like Ataxia-telangiectasia, which involves neurodegeneration and immune system issues C) Homologous recombination is a repair mechanism for double-strand breaks in DNA. Defects in this pathway, such as mutations in the BRCA genes, predispose individuals to breast and ovarian cancers D) Mismatch repair (MMR) corrects base-pair mismatches during DNA replication. Defects in this pathway are associated with Lynch syndrome, increasing the risk of colorectal, endometrial, and other cancers

questions.text: A 45 year male Patient presents with fever, hepatosplenomegaly, TLC 40000, genetic shows karyotype 46 XY, with t (9;22) what is likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) T (9;22) is the characteristic Philadelphia chromosome translocation commonly associated with CML. This translocation results in the BCR-ABL fusion gene, which leads to the uncontrolled growth of leukemic cells, typically presenting with symptoms like fever, hepatosplenomegaly, and elevated TLC Other options: A) AML (Acute Myeloid Leukemia): AML is not typically associated with the Philadelphia chromosome translocation C) ALL (Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia): While the Philadelphia chromosome can be seen in B-cell ALL, it is more commonly linked to CML D) CLL (Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia): CLL is not associated with the Philadelphia chromosome

questions.text: A young athlete collapses on the field histology of heart is as shows what is likely diagnosis.Biopsy from heart is as follows what is likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Boxcar nuclei in heart histology refer to the arranged nuclei seen in HOCM. In HOCM, there is abnormal thickening of the heart muscle, especially the septum, leading to obstruction of blood flow and potential collapse or sudden cardiac death, especially in young athletes Other options: B) Amyloidosis: Involves extracellular amyloid deposits in the heart, but not typically associated with "boxcar" nuclei C) DCMP (Dilated Cardiomyopathy): Involves ventricular dilation and poor contraction, but it doesn't show boxcar nuclei D) MI (Myocardial Infarction): Would show necrotic tissue and may have areas of fibrosis, but not boxcar nuclei

questions.text: A patient presents with respiratory distress and has pan acinar emphysema, which of the following is deficient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency is a genetic disorder that causes panacinar emphysema, particularly in younger individuals and non-smokers. It leads to the destruction of alveolar walls due to a lack of inhibition of neutrophil elastase, which causes damage to the lungs, resulting in emphysema. Other options: A) Surfactant A: Involved in innate immunity in the lungs, but its deficiency is not primarily associated with panacinar emphysema B) Surfactant B: Deficiency of this surfactant protein is linked to neonatal respiratory distress syndrome, not panacinar emphysema D) Albumin: A protein involved in maintaining oncotic pressure, not related to emphysema

questions.text: Which of the following disease follows the pattern of inheritance shown below?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder, meaning the pattern of inheritance follows the X-linked recessive mode. This condition primarily affects males and results in eczema, thrombocytopenia, and immunodeficiency. Other options: A) Achondroplasia: This is an autosomal dominant disorder, not X-linked B) Wilson disease: This is an autosomal recessive disorder and does not follow the X-linked pattern C) Prader-Willi syndrome: This is a genetic imprinting disorder caused by the loss of paternal gene expression and does not follow typical inheritance patterns like X-linked recessive inheritance

questions.text: Based on chromosomal pattern given in the image what is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Prader-Willi Syndrome (PWS) occurs due to a loss of function of genes on the paternal chromosome 15q11–q13 region. This can happen via: • Deletion of the paternal segment (as shown in the image), • Maternal uniparental disomy (both chromosomes inherited from the mother), • Or imprinting defects. PWS is characterized by: • Hypotonia in infancy • Poor feeding early on, followed by hyperphagia and obesity • Developmental delay • Hypogonadism Incorrect Options: A. Angelman Syndrome: • Also involves the 15q11–q13 region, but due to maternal deletion or mutation in UBE3A gene. • The image shows a paternal deletion, so this is not Angelman. C. Cri du chat Syndrome: • Caused by deletion on chromosome 5p, not 15. • Characterized by a cat-like cry, intellectual disability, and facial dysmorphism. D. Rett Syndrome: • Caused by mutation in MECP2 gene on X chromosome. • Affects mostly females, with normal early development followed by regression.

choices.text: Flow cytometry is gold standard for diagnosis
Heart failure is most common cause of death

questions.text: True about PNH
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Flow cytometry is gold standard for diagnosis: Flow cytometry is the gold standard for diagnosing PNH. It detects the absence of specific markers (CD55 and CD59) on red blood cells, which are characteristic of the condition due to a defect in the PIGA gene. Other options: A) Sucrose lysis test is diagnostic: The sucrose lysis test can be used as an initial screening test for paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH), but it is not the gold standard. This test is less specific and can lead to false positives, so it is not diagnostic by itself C) Inherited: PNH is acquired, not inherited. It results from a somatic mutation in the PIGA gene in hematopoietic stem cells, leading to a clonal expansion of defective cells D) Heart failure is most common cause of death: While thrombosis (particularly in unusual sites like the hepatic veins) is the leading cause of death in PNH, heart failure is not the most common cause

questions.text: Elderly patient with CRAB +ve, M protein >3g/dL, serum electrophoresis is as follows, what is likely diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) IgM multiple myeloma is the subtype of multiple myeloma. It is characterized by the presence of M-protein (monoclonal IgM), and the clinical features such as hypercalcemia, renal failure, anemia, and bone lesions (often seen in multiple myeloma) match well with this diagnosis. The presence of the M band in the M region on serum electrophoresis supports this diagnosis Other options: A) IgM, MGUS: Monoclonal Gammopathy of Undetermined Significance (MGUS) typically presents with a monoclonal protein (M-protein) in serum electrophoresis but without the symptoms or organ damage seen in multiple myeloma. The presence of hypercalcemia, renal failure, anemia, and bone lesions points more towards active multiple myeloma rather than MGUS D) Smouldering myeloma: Smouldering multiple myeloma involves elevated M-protein levels without the organ damage (hypercalcemia, renal failure, anemia, bone lesions) typically seen in active multiple myeloma. The clinical symptoms here suggest active myeloma rather than smouldering

questions.text: Histology of MI is as below what is likely age of infarct?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The image displays two critical histological features that are highly indicative of the early stages of a myocardial infarction: Coagulative Necrosis: This is the characteristic type of cell death in myocardial infarction, where the basic cell outlines are preserved but the nuclei are lost. This morphological change becomes discernible under a light microscope typically within 4-12 hours of irreversible ischemic injury and is well-established by 18-24 hours. The image clearly labels areas showing this feature. Dense Neutrophilic Infiltrate: Neutrophils are the first and most numerous inflammatory cells to migrate into the infarcted area. They begin to appear in significant numbers around 12-24 hours after the onset of ischemia, and by 24 hours (1 day), they form a dense infiltrate throughout the necrotic tissue. The image explicitly labels a "Dense neutrophilic infiltrate," which precisely matches the findings expected at this time point. The simultaneous presence of well-developed coagulative necrosis and a dense neutrophilic infiltrate strongly points to an infarct age of approximately 1 day. Incorrect Options: Option (B. 3-4 days) Explanation: While a dense neutrophilic infiltrate would still be present at 3-4 days, this period also marks the beginning of macrophage infiltration (to clear debris) and the start of granulation tissue formation (fibroblasts and new blood vessels). The image, with its overwhelming neutrophil presence and lack of clear signs of macrophage dominance or early granulation tissue, is less characteristic of 3-4 days compared to 1 day. Option (C. 7 days) Explanation: By 7 days, the histological picture changes significantly. Macrophages would be the predominant inflammatory cell type, actively clearing necrotic debris. More importantly, well-formed granulation tissue (composed of fibroblasts, new capillaries, and chronic inflammatory cells) would be clearly evident, indicating the repair phase. Neutrophils would have largely diminished. The image does not show these features. Option (D. 14 days) Explanation: At 14 days, the healing process is well advanced. The infarct area would largely consist of robust granulation tissue with significant collagen deposition, leading towards scar formation. Acute inflammatory cells like neutrophils would be almost entirely absent, and macrophages would also be less prominent as the debris clearance nears completion. The image clearly shows an acute inflammatory response, not a healing scar.

questions.text: Cervical lymph node biopsy is as below, what Is likely diagnosis?treatment ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The biopsy description showing Reed-Sternberg cells is pathognomonic for Hodgkin Lymphoma (HL). These cells are large, binucleated cells with prominent nucleoli, often described as "owl-eye" in appearance. The standard first-line treatment for Hodgkin Lymphoma is the ABVD regimen, which includes • Adriamycin (doxorubicin) • Bleomycin • Vinblastine • Dacarbazine Other options: B) NHL-RCHOP regimen: R-CHOP (Rituximab, Cyclophosphamide, Doxorubicin, Vincristine, Prednisone) is used for Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma (NHL), not HL C) HL-RCHOP regimen: R-CHOP is not the standard treatment for HL D) NHL-ABVD regimen: ABVD is not used for NHL

questions.text: Which antibody is associated with celiac disease?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Celiac disease is an autoimmune disorder triggered by gluten in genetically predisposed individuals.
