The most sensitive and specific antibody associated with celiac disease is Anti-Tissue Transglutaminase (Anti-TTG) IgA Other options: A) ANA (Antinuclear Antibodies): Associated with autoimmune diseases such as lupus but not specific to celiac disease B) AMA (Anti-Mitochondrial Antibodies): Found in primary biliary cholangitis, not celiac disease D) ANCA (Anti-Neutrophil Cytoplasmic Antibodies): Linked to vasculitis conditions like granulomatosis with polyangiitis, not celiac disease

questions.text: A patient had pulmonary hemorrhage and hematuria, PANCA was positive, what is likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Microscopic Polyangiitis (MPA) is a small-vessel vasculitis that commonly presents with pulmonary hemorrhage (alveolar hemorrhage), hematuria (due to glomerulonephritis), and is associated with p-ANCA (anti-MPO antibodies). MPA does not involve granuloma formation, which distinguishes it from Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA) Other options: A) Goodpasture Syndrome: This presents with pulmonary hemorrhage and hematuria but is associated with anti-GBM antibodies, not p-ANCA C) Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA): It also presents with pulmonary and renal involvement but is associated with c-ANCA (anti-PR3 antibodies) and granulomatous inflammation D) PAN (Polyarteritis Nodosa): It involves medium-sized vessels, does not typically cause glomerulonephritis or pulmonary hemorrhage, and is not associated with p-ANCA

questions.text: In a thalassaemic patient which virus would attack the stem cells of bone marrow and cause aplasia?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Parvovirus B19 is a DNA virus that specifically targets and infects erythroid progenitor cells in the bone marrow by binding to the P antigen on their surface. In patients with thalassemia, who already have increased red blood cell turnover, Parvovirus B19 infection can lead to aplastic crisis (temporary cessation of red blood cell production) because their bone marrow cannot compensate for the reduced erythropoiesis Other options: A) HBV (Hepatitis B virus): This virus primarily affects the liver and does not directly attack bone marrow stem cells C) CMV (Cytomegalovirus): CMV can cause bone marrow suppression but does not specifically target erythroid progenitors D) EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus): EBV is associated with lymphoproliferative disorders and does not cause aplastic crisis or selective erythroid aplasia

questions.text: A patient presents with easy fatigue, BM shows 22% plasma cells and the biopsy is as given below, what is likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Amyloidosis is a condition characterized by the deposition of amyloid proteins in various tissues, including the bone marrow. The presence of plasma cells (22%) in the bone marrow along with amyloid deposits can suggest primary (AL) amyloidosis, which is often associated with plasma cell dyscrasias, such as multiple myeloma. Amyloid deposits can be seen in the bone marrow biopsy as apple-green birefringence when stained with Congo red under polarized light. Fatigue is a common symptom of amyloidosis, particularly due to organ involvement such as the kidneys or heart Other options: A) Fibrinoid necrosis of bone marrow: This is more typically seen in vasculitis or autoimmune conditions, not in amyloidosis B) Tuberculosis: While tuberculosis can involve the bone marrow, it typically presents with granulomas and necrosis, not plasma cells and amyloid deposits D) Coagulative necrosis of bone marrow: This is more commonly seen in ischemic or infarction events, not in amyloidosis

questions.text: An adult male presented with bloating sensation, diarrhoea, weight loss. Peripheral blood smear is sa shown. Likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Acanthocytes on peripheral blood smear are characteristic of abetalipoproteinemia. These are abnormally shaped red blood cells with projections (spiky appearance). Abetalipoproteinemia is a rare inherited disorder that affects the body's ability to produce apolipoprotein B, which is essential for the assembly and secretion of lipoproteins. It leads to malabsorption of fats and fat-soluble vitamins, resulting in symptoms such as bloating, diarrhoea, and weight loss Other options: B) Celiac disease: This is typically associated with malabsorption, diarrhea, and weight loss, but acanthocytes are not a feature. Celiac disease would show villous atrophy in the small intestine on biopsy, and anti-tTG antibodies in the blood C) Whipple disease: This rare bacterial infection can cause malabsorption, diarrhea, and weight loss, but it would present with periodic acid-Schiff (PAS)-positive macrophages in the small intestine and does not typically cause acanthocytes D) MAHA (Microangiopathic Hemolytic Anemia): This condition leads to hemolysis, but acanthocytes are not a feature. MAHA is often seen in conditions like HUS or TTP, where you would find fragmented red blood cells (schistocytes) instead of acanthocytes

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed of tumor in the lung, TTF-1 immunohistochemistry is as shown below what is likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) TTF-1 (Thyroid Transcription Factor-1) is a protein that is commonly expressed in lung adenocarcinoma, as well as in thyroid tissue. In lung adenocarcinoma, TTF-1 is often positive, which helps to distinguish it from other types of lung cancer. If the TTF-1 immunohistochemistry result shows positive staining, it strongly supports the diagnosis of adenocarcinoma of the lung Incorrect Options: A) Small cell carcinoma: This type of lung cancer generally does not express TTF-1. Small cell carcinoma is more likely to show positive staining for neuroendocrine markers, but not for TTF-1 in the same way as adenocarcinoma B) Squamous cell carcinoma: This cancer type is typically TTF-1 negative, and it usually expresses markers such as P40 and CK5/6 D) Carcinoid: This is a type of neuroendocrine tumor and would also likely be negative for TTF-1, with a more typical staining pattern for neuroendocrine markers (e.g., chromogranin, synaptophysin)

questions.text: A child presents with itching skin lesions and diarrhoea, he was put on gluten free diet for treatment. Likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Celiac disease is an autoimmune disorder that affects the small intestine when gluten (a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye) is consumed. Symptoms of celiac disease include diarrhea, weight loss, bloating, and itchy skin lesions (called dermatitis herpetiformis). Dermatitis herpetiformis is strongly associated with celiac disease and presents as a blistering, itchy rash. The gluten-free diet is the primary treatment for celiac disease, which helps control symptoms and prevent damage to the intestines Other options: B) Whipple disease: This is a rare bacterial infection caused by Tropheryma whipplei and typically presents with symptoms such as diarrhea, weight loss, and joint pain, but does not specifically cause itchy skin lesions C) Abetalipoproteinemia: This is a rare genetic disorder causing malabsorption, lipid deficiencies, and neurologic symptoms, but it does not commonly present with itching or skin lesions D) Tropical sprue: This is a condition caused by an unknown infectious agent, leading to malabsorption, diarrhea, and weight loss, but it does not typically present with itchy skin lesions

questions.text: A 23-year female whose height is 4 feet and karyotype is given below what is likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Turner syndrome is a genetic condition that affects females, where one of the X chromosomes is missing or partially missing. This results in a karyotype of 45, X0 (only one X chromosome instead of two). Common features include short stature (e.g., 4 feet in this case), ovarian failure, and absence of secondary sexual characteristics. Other possible features include a webbed neck, heart defects, and learning difficulties Incorrect Options: A) Edwards syndrome (Trisomy 18): This condition involves an extra chromosome 18 (47, XX/XY, +18) and is associated with severe developmental and physical disabilities, but not the karyotype seen in this patient (45, X0) C) Klinefelter syndrome: This is a condition in males where there is an extra X chromosome, resulting in a karyotype of 47, XXY. It does not match the patient's karyotype or symptoms D) Down syndrome (Trisomy 21): This involves an extra chromosome 21 (47, XX/XY, +21) and typically presents with developmental delay, intellectual disabilities, and characteristic facial features, but not a missing X chromosome

questions.text: Transferrin saturation in Iron deficiency anemia
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Transferrin saturation refers to the percentage of transferrin (the protein that carries iron in the blood) that is bound to iron. In iron deficiency anemia, there is a decrease in transferrin saturation because there is less iron available to bind to transferrin. As a result, transferrin becomes less saturated with iron Other options: B) Increases: Transferrin saturation would not increase in iron deficiency anemia, as there is insufficient iron C) Normal: Transferrin saturation is typically decreased in iron deficiency anemia D) None of the above: This is incorrect, as the correct answer is A

questions.text: A female presents with easy fatigue, blood examination shows decreased Hb, Serum Iron is low, TIBC is high, ferritin is low, what is likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The patient presents with easy fatigue, and blood tests show decreased hemoglobin, low serum iron, high TIBC (total iron-binding capacity), and low ferritin. These findings are classic for iron deficiency anemia. In iron deficiency anemia, there is a lack of iron available for hemoglobin production, resulting in a low serum iron and low ferritin (which stores iron in the body). The body compensates by increasing the production of transferrin, which results in a high TIBC Other options: B) Sideroblastic anemia: This type of anemia involves impaired incorporation of iron into hemoglobin, but ferritin levels are usually normal or elevated, not low, and TIBC would be normal, not high C) Anemia of chronic disease: In anemia of chronic disease, ferritin is usually normal or elevated, and TIBC is low, opposite to what is seen in this patient D) Thalassemia minor: Thalassemia is typically characterized by microcytic anemia with normal or elevated ferritin levels, and TIBC is usually normal

questions.text: A factory worker working for 20 years presents with breathlessness, lung biopsy is as follows, likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Asbestosis is a lung disease caused by inhaling asbestos fibers, which can lead to lung scarring and respiratory symptoms. The key finding on the lung biopsy showing asbestos bodies confirms the diagnosis of asbestosis. Asbestos bodies are characteristic of inhaled asbestos fibers that become coated with iron-containing proteins, making them visible on histology Other options: A) Coal worker pneumoconiosis: This disease is caused by inhalation of coal dust and typically shows coal macules on biopsy, not asbestos bodies C) Silicosis: Caused by inhalation of silica dust, it typically shows silicotic nodules or dust-laden macrophages, not asbestos bodies D) Tuberculosis: Tuberculosis can cause lung damage, but it would show granulomas or caseous necrosis on biopsy, not asbestos bodies

questions.text: Not seen in ileal resection is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Ileal resection can result in several complications, but microcytic anemia is typically not one of them. The ileum plays a key role in absorbing vitamin B12 and bile salts. When the ileum is resected or damaged, it can lead to macrocytic anemia (due to vitamin B12 deficiency) and other nutritional deficiencies, but microcytic anemia is more commonly associated with iron deficiency, which is typically not caused by ileal resection. Other options: A) Neurological manifestations: These can occur due to vitamin B12 deficiency following ileal resection, leading to neuropathy or dementia B) Reversible dementia: This can occur due to vitamin B12 deficiency, which is often seen after ileal resection, causing cognitive changes that can improve with treatment D) Nucleocytoplasmic asynchrony: This refers to a characteristic finding in megaloblastic anemia, which is common in patients with vitamin B12 deficiency, another potential complication of ileal resection

questions.text: A child has recurrent infections, X ray shows absent thymic shadow, further investigations show ADA levels are low, what is likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) SCID is a primary immunodeficiency disorder that results in severe impairment of both T-cell and B-cell functions, leading to recurrent infections. It is caused by a variety of genetic mutations, and one of the most common defects is adenosine deaminase (ADA) deficiency, which is responsible for the accumulation of toxic metabolites in immune cells, leading to their dysfunction. A thymic shadow on an X-ray may be diminished or absent in SCID due to the absence or dysfunction of T-cells, which are crucial for thymic development and function Other options: A) DiGeorge syndrome: This is caused by a deletion on chromosome 22q11 and typically results in thymic hypoplasia or aplasia leading to T-cell deficiency. However, ADA levels are usually normal in DiGeorge syndrome C) Bruton agammaglobulinemia: This is a B-cell immunodeficiency caused by mutations in the BTK gene, resulting in absent B-cells and immunoglobulins. It does not affect ADA levels D) Ataxia telangiectasia: This is a disorder of DNA repair characterized by ataxia, telangiectasia, and immunodeficiency. It is not associated with low ADA levels

questions.text: A patient presents with hypertension, urinary VMA is positive, histology of tumor is showing Zellballen appearance. what is true about this tumor?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Pheochromocytoma is a tumor that originates from the adrenal medulla and secretes catecholamines, which causes symptoms like hypertension, headaches, palpitations, and sweating. Elevated urinary VMA (vanillylmandelic acid) is a common diagnostic marker for pheochromocytomas. In MEN-2A, pheochromocytomas are often bilateral, and the syndrome is associated with other endocrine abnormalities, such as medullary thyroid carcinoma. This association makes MEN-2A a plausible diagnosis in this case Other options: A) Mostly malignant: Pheochromocytomas are typically benign (85-90% of cases), although a small proportion can be malignant. The histological features and the clinical presentation would help in differentiating malignant from benign cases. Therefore, "Mostly malignant" is not true for pheochromocytomas B) Children: Pheochromocytomas are rare in children but can occur, especially in the context of genetic syndromes. However, they are more common in adults, particularly those in their 40s to 50s. So, "children" is not the most appropriate answer here C) Bilateral: Bilateral pheochromocytomas are more likely in genetic syndromes such as MEN-2, von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) syndrome, and Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). However, most pheochromocytomas are unilateral, especially in sporadic cases. Bilateral pheochromocytomas would suggest a genetic cause like MEN-2A or VHL

questions.text: A tall adult male has pectus excavatum and cardiac abnormality, likely mutation?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Fibrillin is the protein mutated in Marfan syndrome, a connective tissue disorder that leads to tall stature, pectus excavatum, and cardiovascular abnormalities like aortic aneurysms and valvular defects Other options: A) Collagen: Collagen mutations are associated with various connective tissue disorders, but the hallmark of Marfan syndrome and similar syndromes is typically related to fibrillin rather than collagen B) Elastin: Elastin mutations lead to disorders like Williams syndrome, which presents with features such as cardiovascular issues, but it does not typically cause pectus excavatum or tall stature like Marfan syndrome does C) Laminin: Laminin mutations are related to certain muscular dystrophies, and are not typically associated with the findings of pectus excavatum, tall stature, or cardiovascular abnormalities

choices.text: Serum iron measured is bound to apoferritin
Iron is stored in tissue in the form of ferritin and hemosiderin
Serum ferritin is most convenient test for iron stores

questions.text: True about iron are all except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Serum iron is typically bound to transferrin, a transport protein, and not to apoferritin. Apoferritin is the iron-free form of ferritin, which stores iron inside cells Other options: A) Free iron is toxic: Free iron can catalyze the formation of free radicals, which can cause cellular damage, contributing to oxidative stress. This is why iron in the body is tightly regulated and typically bound to proteins like transferrin or ferritin C) Iron is stored in tissue in the form of ferritin and hemosiderin: Ferritin is the main storage form of iron in tissues, and hemosiderin is a less readily accessible form of iron that forms when ferritin is overloaded. Both are found primarily in the liver, spleen, and bone marrow D) Serum ferritin is the most convenient test for iron stores: Serum ferritin levels are an indicator of the body's iron stores. Low ferritin levels often suggest iron deficiency, while elevated ferritin can indicate iron overload or inflammation

questions.text: Modern investigation that has replaced clotting time to evaluate intrinsic pathway is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) APTT evaluates the intrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade, which involves factors I (fibrinogen), II (prothrombin), V, VIII, IX, X, XI, and XII. It has largely replaced clotting time as a more accurate and standardized test for assessing the intrinsic pathway Other options: A) PT (Prothrombin Time): PT primarily evaluates the extrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade, particularly factors I (fibrinogen), II (prothrombin), V, VII, and X. It is not used to assess the intrinsic pathway B) TT (Thrombin Time): TT measures the conversion of fibrinogen to fibrin, specifically assessing fibrinogen levels and thrombin activity. It is not used to evaluate the intrinsic pathway D) Clot retraction time: This is a very old test that was used to assess platelet function and the ability of blood clots to retract. It has largely been replaced by more modern tests like platelet aggregation studies

questions.text: Which protein is deposited in alzhiemers disease
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Beta-amyloid plaques are the hallmark deposits in Alzheimer's disease. These plaques are made up of fragments of a larger protein called amyloid precursor protein (APP), which aggregates into toxic plaques that accumulate between nerve cells in the brain, leading to neurodegeneration Other options: A) Alpha-synuclein: Alpha-synuclein is the protein associated with Parkinson's disease and Lewy body dementia, not Alzheimer's disease C) Dystrophin: Dystrophin is a protein involved in muscular dystrophy, specifically Duchenne muscular dystrophy. It is not associated with Alzheimer's disease D) Lamin: Lamin is a protein found in the nuclear envelope and is associated with various nuclear structural disorders, not Alzheimer's disease

questions.text: A child presents with lymphadenopathy, biopsy shows small neoplastic cells positive for CD 19, CD20, CD10 and negative for CD 5, TdT, CD23. WHAT IS LIKELY DIAGNOSIS?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Burkitt lymphoma is a type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma characterized by small round cells with a high mitotic index, often with CD10, CD19, and CD20 positivity. The negative CD5, CD23, and TdT rules out other B-cell lymphomas like small lymphocytic lymphoma or diffuse large B-cell lymphoma Other options: A) B-lymphoblastic lymphoma: B-lymphoblastic lymphoma is characterized by the presence of immature B-cells, typically positive for TdT (Terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase) and CD34, which is not seen in this case. The negative TdT makes B-lymphoblastic lymphoma less likely C) Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL): DLBCL typically presents with large, atypical cells, and positivity for CD19 and CD20, but it also tends to be positive for CD5 in some cases. The histology and immunophenotype in this case do not match DLBCL, which is more heterogeneous in cell size and appearance D) Small lymphoblastic lymphoma: Small lymphoblastic lymphoma typically involves small, mature lymphocytes, with a CD5, CD23, and TdT positivity. The absence of CD5 and CD23 makes small lymphoblastic lymphoma less likely

choices.text: Type II has severe deficiency of VWF

questions.text: Which of the following is false about von Willebrand disease?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) This statement is false, which makes it the correct answer to the question "Which of the following is false about von Willebrand disease?" • Type I von Willebrand disease is the most common and usually the mildest form. • It is characterized by a partial quantitative deficiency of von Willebrand factor (VWF). • Most patients have mild to moderate bleeding symptoms, not severe disease. • Therefore, calling Type I "severe" is inaccurate, making this the correct choice for a false statement. Incorrect Options: B. Type II is qualitative disorder This statement is true. • Type II vWD is due to a qualitative defect in the structure or function of VWF. • The amount of VWF may be normal or slightly decreased, but it doesn't work properly. • So, this is a correct statement and not the correct answer to the question. C. Type II has severe deficiency of VWF • This statement is somewhat misleading but still generally considered false, because: • Type II is defined by qualitative defects, not a severe quantitative deficiency. • The amount of VWF may be mildly decreased, but not severely deficient like in Type III. However, since this isn't as clearly false as option A, A is still the best choice for the "false" statement. D. Type III is severe • This statement is true. • Type III vWD is the rarest and most severe form of the disease. • It involves a near-complete or total deficiency of VWF. • Patients with Type III typically have severe bleeding symptoms, similar to hemophilia. So this is a correct statement, and not the correct answer to the question.

questions.text: Patient has history of cough and respiratory discomfort for 1 month and hilar lymphadenopathy, biopsy shows granulomas with Stellate inclusions what is likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Stellate lesions are nothing but description of asteroid bodies which are star shaped inclusions within granulomas seen in sarcoidosis.

questions.text: Histopathological examination of lymphnode is a 50-year-old patient shows Neoplastic lymphocytes positive for CD10, BCL-2. Which of the following translocation is likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) CD10 and Bcl-2 positive means this is follicular lymphoma, which shows t(14;18)

questions.text: Bone marrow aspirate from elderly male patient having recurrent infections, bleeding, BMA shows 25% blasts as below, what translocation is likely to be seen
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) BM shows blasts with multiple auer rods which are seen in acute promyelocytic leukaemia, which shows t(15;17)

questions.text: A patient diagnosed of depleted factor IX, the disease got corrected with injection of Vitamin K. which of the following could be etiology?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Factor IX deficiency getting corrected with vitamin K means it is vitamin K deficiency. Vitamin K being fat soluble vitamin will be deficient in fat malabsorption ( bile duct obstruction causes fat malabsorption)

questions.text: A patient underwent ileal resection following which he developed anemia, Hb 9, MCV 110. What is likely etiology
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ileum is where vitamin B12 gets absorbed and macrocytic anemia after Ileal resection makes it B12 deficiency.

questions.text: A child has presented with fatigue, Jaundice and Splenomegaly. MCHC is increased. His father also has similar history. Which of the following is most likely diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Increased MCHC is seen in speherocytosis, child with jaundice, family history positive (dominant) thus hereditary spherocytosis.

questions.text: Which of the following uses caspases in its action
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Cascades are activated in Apoptosis and Pyroptosis

questions.text: Histological examination of a neck tumor shows tumor cells positive for synaptophysin, Chromogranin, TTF-1 and there is amyloid material deposited in the tissue. What is likely diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Presence of amyloid in a neck tumor is suggestive of medullary thyroid carcinoma, which is also positive for Chromogranin, synaptophysi.

questions.text: Child presents with severe infections, decreased B and T cells, decreased ADA which of the following is diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Decreased B and T cells suggests combined immunodeficiency, decreased ADA (adenosine deamiase ) is SCID

questions.text: Which of the following disease follows the pattern of inheritance shown below
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The pedigree shows mother to 100% children and fac=ther to 0% transmission which is seen in mitochondrial and option A is mitochondrial.

choices.text: No change in protein = no disease
The protein change will get corrected by post transcriptional modification
Complete biological loss of protein, disease

questions.text: In a protein which has 900 amino acids, there is a frame shift mutation at 4th nucleotide which of the following will happen
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Frame shift leads to loss of function of original protein and gain of function of new protein.

questions.text: Cut section of testicular tumor is grey white and homogenous without hemorrhage or necrosis what tumor is it? Microscopy image is as shown below likely diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Histology shows fibrous septal with lymphocyte and clear cytoplasm which are seen in seminoma

questions.text: Histological examination of lung shows pink frothy material and hemosiderin laden macrophages. Which of the following is not likely cause?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Hhistological description is suggestive of pulmonary edema, option A does not cause pulmonary edema.

questions.text: A girl presents with photosensitive skin lesions BCC on face, which of the following abnormality is likely to be seen
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) BCC and photosensitive skin lesions are seen in Xeroderma pigmentosa, which shows NER.

questions.text: Identify the following structure
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The epithelium is of transitional type which is seen in ureter

questions.text: A child presents with visual disturbance. Imaging shows supra sellar tumor. Histopathology shows anucleate squames and wet keratin. What is likely diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Suprasellar tumor+ Anucleate squames and wet keratin is characteristic of Craniopharynfioma.

questions.text: CD markers can be detected by which of the following test
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Flow cytometry is used for assessing CD markers.

questions.text: A patient presents with imbalance, verigo. CP angle mass was seen on imaging. Histological examination of tumor shows Antoni A and B with Verocay bodies areas
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Antoni A, B and Verona’s bodies are characteristic of schwannoma

questions.text: Young lady presents with jaundice pruritis, Antimitochondrial antibodies are elevated. Liver biopsy shows lymphocytic and plasma cell infiltrate in bileduct. What is likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) AMA and lymphocytic and plasma cell infirltrate in bile ducts is characteristic of PBC

questions.text: Cut section of liver mass is as shown in the image likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Stellate lesion on gross is characteristic of FNH

questions.text: A child presents with lens dislocation, tall stature. Which gene is mutated.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Clinically this is Marian’s syndrome which has fibrilling (FBN) mutation.
